projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: TARLETONS Tragical Treatises, Contaynyng sundrie discourses and prety Conceytes, both in Prose and Verse.
Imprinted at London by Henry Bynneman.

div.head: ¶ To the right honourable and vertuous Lady, the Lady Frauncis Mildmay, Richard Tarleton wisheth long life, and prosperous health, with happy encrease of Honor.
div.p:
WHEN I throughly conferred, (right Honourable and my very good Lady) your noble forwardenesse in all godly Literature, your graue and approued iudgement, with my base simplicitie, and slender vnderstanding: I stoode houering a great while betwene the extremities of a double doubt, whether I were beste to sollicite your good Ladiship with the view of these thrift lesse lines or no. But when I called to mynde your Honors courteous disposition of Nature, and readye inclination to accept of the trauells of all suche as do but stande aloofe, yet beare a certaine peculiar reuerence to good letters, a freshe hope so armde or rather warmde my former frosen doubt, that all feare sette aparte, I
rashly aduentured the publishing of this peeuish Pamphlet vnder the patronage of your Honors name: where I knowe it may haue as safe a refuge, as if it were protected vnder the Target of Minerua, againste the poisoned Inuectiues & malicious reproches of all slaunderous tongs. Perhaps (Madam) your Honor wyll haue me in some suspition of Arrogancie, in as muche as I haue presumed to trouble, or rather weary your honorable eares with so vaine an argument, as these fantasticall trifles: But yet my faithfull and affectionate zeale (vnto youre good Ladiship so forwardly addicted) had in due consideration: my ouer boldnesse may be rather attributed to my want of knowlege, than presumption, in as much as your Honor is not altogither ignorant, that I neuer marched among the Muses, nor serued in the campe where Learning as Chieftaine had hir sacred residence. But had I Platoes diuine Im • ginations, Aristotles Philosophy, Archi 〈…〉 e's Geometrie, Orpheus Musicke, or Tullies Eloquence, yet wold I not haue such a glorious opinion of my own excellency, but I could willingly, and would moste gladly
submit my selfe, my skill, and all vnto your Ladiships approued iudgement, and fauorable protection: especially, being one, whose honorable opinion of my poore skill vnworthily, and manifolde bounties vndeserued, haue bin sundrye times of my parte well proued and tasted, to my no little credite, and very great benefite. I might haue taken sufficient occasion in these superfluous Pamphlets to haue entred into a necessary Enchomiasticon of your Honors sundrye good vertues and noble qualities, if without the helpe of my barren blazoning, they were not already so notified to all the worlde, that youre Ladiships iust praises are in euery mans mouth: and besids in the attempting of it, there depēds a double daunger. Firste, leaste seeming to wade so farre into the discourse thereof, as the matter yeelds iuste scope, by this meanes I get the name and note of a Thrasonicall Clawback: The other doubt is, leaste vndertaking so difficulte a taske, and not able to discharge it according to the dignitie and worthinesse thereof, I wrappe my selfe in such an intricate Labyrinth, that I shall hardely winde my selfe out without
some spotte, or blemishe to my credite. And therefore I will yeelde thaccomplishing of that enterprise to other, whose Muse ca better wade through so daungerous a forde, than mine.
Meane space in moste deuout maner I am to request your Ladiships fauourable acceptation of these treatises, and to esteeme of them, as a perfect testimony of the good heart and dutifull zeale of

closer.signed: Your honors most humble at commaundement, Richard Tarleton, Seruaunt to the right Honourable the Lorde Chamberlaene Earle of Sussex.

div.head: ¶ T. A. in praise of the Authour.

lg.l: FOr him, whome Pallas with hir milke did nurse
And lullabide vpon the Muses lappes,
Tis not so rare to write a braue discourse
Of strange aduentures past, and vncouth happes.
Ne is it harde, a greater taske to welde,
VVhereas the Theame sufficiet scope doth yeeld▪
But hee that neuer tasted Learnings lore,
Nor many a Region nie Pernassus came,
To write in things but seldome seene before,
In that respect demerites double fame:
But specially vpon such toies to write,
As yeelde so little matter to endite.
Then Tarleton thou deseruest double praise,
Sith that with arte so slenderly possest,
Thy Muse hir nature in these toies displaies
More learnedly than any of the rest:
VVhose gifts of Arte so farre inferior be
To those which Nature planted hath in thee.

div.head: Ferdinando Frecleton Gentleman, in praise of these treatises.

lg.l: IF blinde men could of costlie colours iudge,
and intermedle with Apelles arte,
Or were not fretting Enuie giuen to grudge
the faith of him who plaies a friendlie parte,
Or if my skill coulde see in causes deepe,
I would reueale what nowe I secreate keepe.
Yet shall my blunt opinion somewhat reach
beyonde the dombe mindes of the common sort,
My Muse and I shall make a fearefull breache,
if silence hide thy well deservde reporte,
VVhose pleasante heade can cunningly conuey,
In pithie speache thy meaning euerie way.
And where I lookte for manie a wanton drifte,
of tales and ridles in this booke of thine,
Nowe do I see thou canste bestow thy gifte
in grauer geere both learned and diuine,
For (trust me Tarleton) in thy worke a pears,
A platforme that both sense and matter lears.

div.head: Levvis Ph. Gentleman in commendation of the Authour.

lg.l: FAine would I write, yet fainer would I cease,
faine would I tell what truth hath giuen in charge,
The snatching sort do daily so increase
it makes me briefe, that else wold write at large.
Faine would I praise these treaties lately pend,
But that I feare, though causlesse, to offend.
VVhat, shall the labourer then go lose his hire,
whose carefull head hath toilde for our delite,
And all his paines lie tumbled in the mire?
shall slacke regarde his courtesie requite?
No Tarleton, no, I giue thee for amends
A thousand thankes as guerdon from thy friends.
And at thy handes I challenge one requeste,
thy promise partlie yeelds it as my due,
VVhich if performance answer all the rest,
then will I say thy wordes and deeds be true▪
It is thy Theames in order one by one,
To keepe thy fame aliue when thou arte gone.
Yet blame me not good Dicke, though I encroche
to take thy word, as if it were a band:
It is bicause I faine would set abroche
the thing thou closely keepeste in thy hand,
But in meane space thy trifles welcome bee,
And thus farewell, for Theames remember mee.

div.head: The Authours iudgement of such rashe verdicts as are gyuen in dispraise of Poets.

lg.l: IF men may credite such records,
as inke and paper showes
To spring from Poets learned heads,
which cunningly disclose
The strange varieties of things,
the choice of mens delites,
The heauēs, the earth, the seas, the shoare,
the gods, and ghostly sprites,
The secreate mysteries of Starres,
and planets in degrée,
With euery sundry office, that
to them belonging be.
How creatures first receivde their shapes,
how monsters beare the bell,
The glory of celestiall powers,
which in the heauens dwell:

How crooked Chao •
was disperste,
which lay in loathsome lumpes,
Vnfurnished with Natures gifts:
how al things in their dumpes
Lay drownde in silence fearfull pawes,
til rocks were rent asunder,
How at the laste one Lambe by death,
did shew his workes of wonder,
Howe earthly Princes had their rule,
howe came in noble blouds,
How first the artificiall barkes
did cut the foming floudes:
How Sun and Moone do kéepe their course,
how all things in their kinde,
Yéelde reuerence to the sacred seates
of god with harte and minde.
If these things be of true reporte,
as sure no doubt they be,
Deny not Poets their due praise
whose works are lefte to sée:
Their watchfull toile, their busie care,
their quaking hand and quills,
Their whetted wits for knowledge sake:
profoundnesse in their skills,
Doth serue vs as a Christall glasse
to gaze vpon our folly,
Wherin our faults are portrayde out,
though shewes do make vs holy.
But some, whose ydle mindes are bent
to leade a carelesse daunce,
And féede the present time, without
regarde of future chaunce,
Thinke Nature hath bestowde hir gifts
with such sufficient store,
That Arte can stande them small in stéede,
to make their knowledge more.
Thus Fancie féedes their fond conceits,
whereby the swéete delites,
That auntient writers erst haue had
to cheare their dulled sprites,
Are drowned in Obliuions denne,
so wrested, and so wrung,
That all their scrolls and swéete records,
must néeds decay ere long.
The carping crue that holds in spite,
that best contents the wise,
In finding faults with others workes
haue Argus hundred eies:
They rifle volumes leafe by leafe,
verbatim to suruay
The substaunce, or the circumstance:
and then in scorne they say:
This probleme here is ill applide,
that tearme is much abusde.
Here is a lame discourse indéede,
there Priscians pate is brusde:
Thus are the Poets toste and turnde:
their labours rent to ragges:
And all the swéetenesse of their time,
truste vp in Tinkers bagges:
The silly labourer that toiles
in shoures of haile and snow,
Doth make a pastime of his paine,
a welfare of his woe.
Such is his hope, that Vesper commes,
and Phoebus turnde to rest,
He shall receiue his earned due,
to vse as he thinkes best.
So lights the writers lot,
who beates his busied braine,
For no rewarde, but to receiue
goodwill to quite his paine.
The houering Bee that houereth long
about the fragrant floure,
With hoppes and skippes to searh and séeke
the swéete leafe from the soure,
Doth at the laste in quiet hiue
sucke vp the pleasante hony,
Which to hir selfe doth pleasure bring,
and yéeldes hir maister mony.
The labouring Horse, whiche in the yoke
goeth grudging euery day,
At night receiues in shewe of thankes,
both litter, corne and hay.
Then since that neither Bee nor Beast
do thankefulnesse eschue,
Let busy Findfaults cease to grudge,
giue Caesar C • sars due.
But what meane I on such reproofe
to argue all this while?
As though that for a Poets praise
I writ this ragged stile?
Not so, I neuer scalde the cliffe
whereas the sacred nurse
Of learning, hath hir residence,
so much my hap's the worse.
I neuer dranke the dainty drops
that issue from the font,
Wheras eche scholler claimes degrée
to rest in high account,
Yet am I as a subiect sworne
to reuerence their déeds,
And to refreshe their worthy worke,
that darke obliuious wéeds
Not ouergrowe their fragrant floures,
whose vertues do surpasse,
To open secreate mysteries,
which else eclipsed was.
But if my former ydle daies
to study had bin bent,
Or if that God and Fortune to
had giuen their consent,
That I amongste the learned might
haue claimde but lowest roome,
Then in great letters all of golde
vpon Apolloes Toombe,
I woulde haue writ such memories
in honor of his name,
That should haue bin a double meanes
to beautifie his fame.
But wishes nought preuaile,
I yéelde to losse of time,
Sith verse and I so diffrent are,
Ile presse in ragged rime,
To manifest the méere goodwill
that I to learning owe,
No painted words, but perfect déeds,
shall my inuention showe.
Not that I prease for praise,
I shoote not at that white,
But for to conquere sluggish slouth,
I choose this newe delite:
And if these trifles fondly pende
which I present in place,
Not wittily, though willingly
may win your graunt of grace,
Then haue I scalde the doubtfull forte,
the victorie is mine. 〈1+ pages missing〉
